First circumnavigation

One of the most famous Portuguese-born explorers was Fernao de Magalhaes, who instigated and organized the first circumnavigation from 1519 to 1522. Sailing for the King of Spain, he set out to find a route to the Orient, sailing west around the southern tip of South America.

Squadron sailed from Spain

In 1519, a large squadron sailed from Spain, aiming to find a western sea route to Asia. At the head is the Portuguese Fernando Magellan. His five ships sailed farther south along with South America, discovering La Plata Bay, which was originally considered a strait. With many vicissitudes (even a revolt) in 1520, Magellan crossed a narrow and dangerous strait, named today after him

In Progress

"We were all in a good mood again, because we had discovered the strait that many before us had searched in vain," wrote the chronicler Antonio Pigafeta. Magellan then recklessly plunges into the vast expanses of the Pacific Ocean - a time of great suffering for the crew. After more than a hundred days without seeing land, the Spaniards reached the Philippine Islands. The admiral was killed there. All ships except Victoria have been abandoned. In 1522, Victoria returned to Spain laden with spices. Of the 235 sailors, only 18 survive.

Drake message

This first circumnavigation proves something that everyone already knows - that the Earth is round. It shows how big and almost insurmountable the Pacific Ocean is. It reveals more than any other expedition how dangerous a long stay on the high seas is. However, even before the end of the 16th century, the Englishman Francis Drake made a second round-the-world tour. However, it does not pass through the Strait of Magellan, but further south - through the Strait named after him - Drake.
